content.description: The second from the right route.  Really Crimpy and Really Hard for 11d...as I recall.
The left of the two short routes that are on the left side of the right wall at Pirate's Cove.  These two routes really start upon a ledge and are fun but a bit too short.
Just right of CE and left of FFNG.   Crimpy a little soft (at 11d) and not that good.

An easier version of the routes to the right.  On the day of the FA, John Keenan was stung by a Bark Scorpion (Centruroides Excilcauda) that was in a small fissure near the bottom of the route. 

  The bottom is the crux. (Stick clip)
content.protection:
5 or 6 Bolts...I forget.  

This route was bolted solely for the purpose of allowing for the first ascent, and the first ascent information is posted here solely to document the history of the first ascent.  No person should read this posting with the assumption that this route or the fixed gear left behind is safe in any way or otherwise appropriate to allow for safe subsequent ascents.  Climbing is dangerous and should only be done with the appropriate training and risk management practices that include providing for the climber's own safety.  Attempting to climb this route as described above or by any other means or methods could result in injury or death.

content.description: The first route from the left after the 2 short but steep 11b's.  Head left from the first bolt to follow massive jugs to the chains.  This is probably the best route at Pirate's Cove.
Just right of Captain Terry's HSA. This is the 3rd route from the right. Quite a bit harder than Captain Terry's HSA. 10B in Islands in the Sky...but probably more like 10D.
The right of the two short routes that are on the left side of the right wall at Pirate's Cove.  These two routes really start upon a ledge and are fun but a bit too short.
The right-most line on the left wall.  Shares the first bolt with Land-Ho and then follows some sinker holds for 4 more bolts.  I think this is the better of the 11+'s at P-Cove.

This is a small area with sport climbs on conglomerate limestone.  This is not the perfect limestone Mt. Charleston is known for, but the routes are fun.  The cliff gets shade most the day. 

  There are two different sub-areas.   

Left Wall (a hundred yards or so from the left side of the right wall)   Routes from left to right-   Centruroides Excilcauda 10c   Land-Ho 11d   Full Figured Native Girl 11d 

 Right Wall 

  Routes from left to right-   Pieces of Eight 11b   Blood and Swash 11b   Captain Terry's High Sea Adventure 10a    Captain Scott's Maiden Voyage 10b   Salt and Vinegar 11d   Fish and Chips 11b
